paper_title: Enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction over direct Z-scheme NiTiO3/g-C3N4 nanocomposite promoted by efficient interfacial charge transfer

catalyst.source: Herein, to improve the photoreduction efficiency of CO 2 , a direct Z-scheme NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 (NT/GCN) photocatalyst is constructed by a facile calcination method.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to fuels is recognized as a favorable solution to solve the energy crisis and greenhouse effect simultaneously.Herein, to improve the photoreduction efficiency of CO 2 , a direct Z-scheme NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 (NT/GCN) photocatalyst is constructed by a facile calcination method.The highest yield of CH 3 OH (13.74 molg -1 h -1 ) can be obtained at the optimized NT/GCN40 without any sacrificial agent and cocatalyst, almost 3.29 times higher compared with g-C 3 N 4 .Simultaneously, mechanism study by the band potential estimation and electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis provide evidences that the enhanced photoactivity is ascribed to the Z-scheme.This unique structure can enhance the spatial separation of hole-electron pairs, suppress the recombination of charge carriers and remain the strong redox ability.Moreover, this direct Z-scheme NT/GCN40 composite shows good reusability.This work may present a novel way for the design and manufacture of Z-scheme photocatalysts for energy conversion and environmental remediation.

catalyst.source: The NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite was prepared by ultrasoniccalcination method.
catalyst.context: The g-C 3 N 4 nanosheets were fabricated by a thermal treatment of dicyandiamide according to our previous report 11.In a typical process, 2 g of dicyandiamide in an alumina crucible with a lid was put in a muffle furnace and heated to 550 C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 Cmin -1 .After cooling to room temperature, the yellow product was ground into fine power.500 mg of the as-obtained product was added into the mixed solution of 1 mL acetic acid and 25 mL distilled water.Next, the above suspension was stirred for 4 h and then ultrasonicated for 2 h.The sample was collected by centrifugation, washed several times using ethanol and distilled water, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h. The NiTiO 3 nanorods were synthesized by a sol-gel method.Briefly, 3.4 mL Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 (tetrabutyl titanate) and 2.48 g Ni(CH3COO) 2 4H 2 O (nickel acetate tetrahydrate) were dissolved in 60 mL ethylene glycol, followed by stirring at 25 C for 2 h.Then, the bluish precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed several times using distilled water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h.Finally, the powder was calcined at 600 C for 2 h in the muffle furnace to obtain the NiTiO 3 nanorods. The NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite was prepared by ultrasoniccalcination method.In detail, 0.2 g of g-C 3 N 4 and an appropriate amount of NiTiO 3 were dispersed in 30 mL of methanol by ultrasound for 2 h, and then stirred for 6 h.In this process, the NiTiO 3 nanorods would disperse into the g-C 3 N 4 nanoparticles.After that, the yellow slurry was centrifuged and dried in the vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h.Finally, the product was calcined at 400 C for 2 h in the muffle furnace.The samples with NiTiO 3 to NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 mass ratios of 20, 40, 60, 80 were denoted as NT/GCN20, NT/GCN40, NT/GCN60, NT/ GCN80. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Purkinjie XD-3 diffractometer using Cu K radiation.The morphologies and microstructures of the materials were measured by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F30).The electron state and surface composition were assessed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI-5000C ESCA).The UV-vis absorption spectra were carried out on Shimadzu UV-2600 with BaSO 4 as the reference material.The Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area was measured with N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K in the Micromeritics ASAP 2460.CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) experiments were conducted on an automated chemisorption apparatus (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920).Firstly, the sample (0.1 g) was treated under helium flow (50 sccm) up to 300 C at 10 C/min for min and then cooled to 50 C. Secondly, CO 2 (30 sccm) was introduced and adsorbed on the catalyst for 60 min.Thirdly, the sample was flushed by helium flow (30 sccm) for 30 min.Finally, the TPD analysis was carried out under helium flow (30 sccm) with a ramp rate of 10 C/min up to 450 C. Before the measurement, the materials were dried in the vacuum oven at 120 C for 12 h to remove water.The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra was obtained on a Nicolet-iS10 spectrophotometer.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra and time-resolved fluorescence measurements were obtained using a fluorescence spectrometer Edinburgh FLS-980 at an excitation wavelength of 375 nm.The electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis was performed on a Bruker EMX-10/12type spectrometer. The photocurrent response and electrochemistry impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis were conducted on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 760E) in a three-electrode system with Pt wire as a counter electrode, Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode and the photocatalyst as a working electrode.The working electrode was prepared as follows: mg photocatalyst was dispersed in 30 uL nafion and 1 mL ethanol, and then the mixture was treated with sonication for 1 h to make a slurry. Next, 300 L of the slurry was coated onto a 2.0 1.0 cm FTO glass. Finally, the working electrode was dried in a vacuum oven at 150 C. All of the samples were tested in 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte solution. The experiments of CO 2 photoreduction in the presence of H 2 O were performed in a 100 mL autoclave (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd, China) with a quartz window (Fig. S1).The temperature of the reactor was controlled by the circulating water passing through the jacketed wall.A 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a UV cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was employed as the light source.First, 10 mg powder photocatalyst was added in the autoclave of 20 mL distilled water.Second, the autoclave was heated to 80 C by the circulating water from a thermostatic bath, and then vacuumized and filled with CO 2 (99.999) several times to remove the air.Third, 0.6 MPa CO 2 gas was injected into the autoclave and kept in the dark of 30 min to reach adsorptiondesorption equilibrium between the catalyst and CO 2 .Finally, the reaction was carried out under the condition of light illumination and magnetic stirring for 7 h.After that, the reactor was cooled to 25 C. The suspension (2 mL) was gathered and centrifuged in order to remove the particles.The liquid product was analyzed by the gas chromatograph (GC 9860) with a flame ionization detector (FID), a capillary column (PEG-20M, 30 m 0.32 mm 0.5 m) and a headspace autosampler (AHS-12A).The quantum yield for CH 3 OH production was measured in the same process except that a Xe lamp with the wavelength of 420 nm was used as the light source.

reaction medium.context: In summary, a direct Z-scheme composite consisting of NiTiO 3 and g-C 3 N 4 is prepared toward the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in water.This Z-scheme photocatalyst shows enhanced photoactivity for CH 3 OH evolution when compared with g-C 3 N 4 and possesses excellent reusability and quantum yield as well.The improved catalytic performance can be ascribed to efficient carriers separation and migration due to the formation of Z-scheme heterojunction, which could simultaneously maintain the strong reduction capability of g-C 3 N 4 .This study could offer new insight for constructing direct Z-scheme heterojunction to promote the photocatalytic performance of CO 2 reduction.H. reactor type.context: The g-C 3 N 4 nanosheets were fabricated by a thermal treatment of dicyandiamide according to our previous report 11.In a typical process, 2 g of dicyandiamide in an alumina crucible with a lid was put in a muffle furnace and heated to 550 C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 Cmin -1 .After cooling to room temperature, the yellow product was ground into fine power.500 mg of the as-obtained product was added into the mixed solution of 1 mL acetic acid and 25 mL distilled water.Next, the above suspension was stirred for 4 h and then ultrasonicated for 2 h.The sample was collected by centrifugation, washed several times using ethanol and distilled water, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h. The NiTiO 3 nanorods were synthesized by a sol-gel method.Briefly, 3.4 mL Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 (tetrabutyl titanate) and 2.48 g Ni(CH3COO) 2 4H 2 O (nickel acetate tetrahydrate) were dissolved in 60 mL ethylene glycol, followed by stirring at 25 C for 2 h.Then, the bluish precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed several times using distilled water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h.Finally, the powder was calcined at 600 C for 2 h in the muffle furnace to obtain the NiTiO 3 nanorods. The NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite was prepared by ultrasoniccalcination method.In detail, 0.2 g of g-C 3 N 4 and an appropriate amount of NiTiO 3 were dispersed in 30 mL of methanol by ultrasound for 2 h, and then stirred for 6 h.In this process, the NiTiO 3 nanorods would disperse into the g-C 3 N 4 nanoparticles.After that, the yellow slurry was centrifuged and dried in the vacuum oven at 80 C for 12 h.Finally, the product was calcined at 400 C for 2 h in the muffle furnace.The samples with NiTiO 3 to NiTiO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 mass ratios of 20, 40, 60, 80 were denoted as NT/GCN20, NT/GCN40, NT/GCN60, NT/ GCN80. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Purkinjie XD-3 diffractometer using Cu K radiation.The morphologies and microstructures of the materials were measured by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F30).The electron state and surface composition were assessed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI-5000C ESCA).The UV-vis absorption spectra were carried out on Shimadzu UV-2600 with BaSO 4 as the reference material.The Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area was measured with N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K in the Micromeritics ASAP 2460.CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) experiments were conducted on an automated chemisorption apparatus (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920).Firstly, the sample (0.1 g) was treated under helium flow (50 sccm) up to 300 C at 10 C/min for min and then cooled to 50 C. Secondly, CO 2 (30 sccm) was introduced and adsorbed on the catalyst for 60 min.Thirdly, the sample was flushed by helium flow (30 sccm) for 30 min.Finally, the TPD analysis was carried out under helium flow (30 sccm) with a ramp rate of 10 C/min up to 450 C. Before the measurement, the materials were dried in the vacuum oven at 120 C for 12 h to remove water.The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra was obtained on a Nicolet-iS10 spectrophotometer.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra and time-resolved fluorescence measurements were obtained using a fluorescence spectrometer Edinburgh FLS-980 at an excitation wavelength of 375 nm.The electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis was performed on a Bruker EMX-10/12type spectrometer. The photocurrent response and electrochemistry impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis were conducted on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 760E) in a three-electrode system with Pt wire as a counter electrode, Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode and the photocatalyst as a working electrode.The working electrode was prepared as follows: mg photocatalyst was dispersed in 30 uL nafion and 1 mL ethanol, and then the mixture was treated with sonication for 1 h to make a slurry. Next, 300 L of the slurry was coated onto a 2.0 1.0 cm FTO glass. Finally, the working electrode was dried in a vacuum oven at 150 C. All of the samples were tested in 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte solution.
